docs.lead_paragraph: Two widely used treatments for breast cancer -- radiation and the drug Herceptin -- can cause heart problems, researchers are reporting. But the problems can usually be treated or prevented, and they should not scare women away from needed cancer therapies, the doctors say.

headline.main: Treatments For Cancer Are Linked To Heart Ills

docs.abstract: Two new studies show link between increased risk for heart problems and specific breast cancer treatments; Dr Eleanor E R Harris leads study that determines radiation can cause damage to heart, but benefit of cancer treatment still outweighs risk; suggests that those treated with radiation work closely with cardiologist to monitor any heart problems; M D Anderson Cancer Center (Houston) also finds that women taking Herceptin for breast cancer are at increased risk of some treatable heart conditions; both studies are published in Journal of Clinical Oncology (M)
docs.snippet: Two widely used treatments for breast cancer -- radiation and the drug Herceptin -- can cause heart problems, researchers are reporting.      But the problems can usually be treated or prevented, and they should not scare women away from needed...

docs.lead_paragraph: Men with low testosterone were much more likely to die within a specified time frame than their counterparts with normal levels, researchers reported yesterday. Low testosterone levels, common in aging men, are associated with insulin resistance, which can be a precursor of diabetes and other serious diseases.

headline.main: Lower Testosterone Linked to Higher Death Risk

docs.abstract: Dr Molly Shores, University of Washington psychiatry associate professor, leads study on link between morbidity and low testosterone; research, which is published in Archives of Internal Medicine, finds much higher rate of death among men who are over 40 and have low testosterone levels; research does not explore rates among men using testosterone replacement therapy (M)
docs.snippet: Men with low testosterone were much more likely to die within a specified time frame than their counterparts with normal levels, researchers reported yesterday.     Low testosterone levels, common in aging men, are associated with insulin resistance,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who feel anxious during pregnancy should not worry that their feelings will affect their babies, a new report suggests. The report, a review of 50 studies, found no significant associations between feeling anxious and negative outcomes in pregnancy or birth. The findings are online now and will be printed in a future issue of The American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology.

headline.main: Anxious Mothers and Their Calmer Babies

docs.abstract: Heather L Littleton, Sam Houston State University assistant psychology professor, leads study on possible impact of anxiety on mothers-to-be; research, which is published in American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, finds no evidence of negative pregnancy outcomes associated with anxiety; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Women who feel anxious during pregnancy should not worry that their feelings will affect their babies, a new report suggests.      The report, a review of 50 studies, found no significant associations between feeling anxious and negative outcomes in...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN JOURNAL OF OBSTETRICS AND GYNECOLOGY

docs.lead_paragraph: Coffee is not usually thought of as health food, but a number of recent studies suggest that it can be a highly beneficial drink. Researchers have found strong evidence that coffee reduces the risk of several serious ailments, including diabetes, heart disease and cirrhosis of the liver. Among them is a systematic review of studies published last year in The Journal of the American Medical Association, which concluded that habitual coffee consumption was consistently associated with a lower risk of Type 2 diabetes. Exactly why is not known, but the authors offered several explanations.

headline.main: Coffee as a Health Drink? Studies Find Some Benefits

docs.abstract: Several recent studies show that drinking coffee has variety of health benefits, but those benefits decline after six cups in one day; review of studies in Journal of American Medical Assn shows marked decrease in risk of developing Type 2 diabetes among coffee drinkers; decreased risk for heart disease and cirrhosis of liver also noted; possible reasons for findings discussed (M)
